subsc: Central government administration,Roads and highways,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector
trustfund:
TF025240-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT II,TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory.
            Sustainability is likely and depends on the effectiveness of
            the arrangements made for their future operation and
            management. Both World Bank and Borrower performances are
            rated as satisfactory overall. The list of lessons learned
            includes the following: This complex operation involving 12
            government departments made Borrower coordination and
            monitoring and World Bank supervision difficult. It would
            have been better had investments concentrated on fewer
            critical areas that responded most directly to objectives,
            were technically robust, and had a higher chance of success.
            Performance was generally better in those departments that
            commissioned activity evaluation studies early enough and
            then took decisive remedial actions. Continuity of key staff
            contributes to successful implementation. Under typically
            harsh field conditions, especially when migratory practices
            are followed, animal breeding programs should avoid use of
            exotic stock and focus upgrading on selection within the
            locally adapted breeds (except for intensive dairying).
            Future programs should focus on fewer high quality
            demonstrations of technologies with good replication
            prospects. While the project reform agenda successfully
            focused on introducing full cost recovery on selected farm
            inputs, relatively little was included to promote income
            generation and financial sustainability in the implementing departments.
